pr_title: GL-970.  Have CompareMetrics consider two NaN metrics equal

timeline.author: pshapiro4broad

timeline.bodyText:
Under what conditions is it possible for absoluteChange to be non-zero and for (numValue1 == 0 && numValue2 == 0) to be true? Are this trying to avoid dividing by zero?
Also this code now divides by numValue1 and before it divided by numValue2, is that a fix?
timeline.author: pshapiro4broad

replies.bodyText:
Yes, that's to avoid the divide by zero.
I've changed the code to be comparison of the second metric, relative to the first metric, so that's why the denominator has changed.
change = (value2 - value1) / value1
replies.author: gbggrant

replies.bodyText: That explains the second numValue1 == 0 check. But I don't see how (numValue1 == 0 && numValue2 == 0) can be true if absoluteChange is not zero.
replies.author: pshapiro4broad

replies.bodyText: Probably true, the problem with doing lots of incremental changes.
replies.author: gbggrant

replies.bodyText: And it's really not even a problem if the numerator is 0.
replies.author: gbggrant

timeline.message:
GL-970.
Have CompareMetrics consider two NaN metrics equal
Added absolute difference

GL-970.
Have CompareMetrics consider two NaN metrics equal
Added absolute difference
